41.36.text:
— South Korea’s new President Moon Jae-in
has suspended the deployment

44.90.text: of the United States missile defense system,

48.26.text:
He’s called for, quote,
“environmental assessment,” of the system—

52.94.text: Moon was critical of the deployment,

54.64.text: which many South Koreans, as well as China, oppose.

57.92.text: If the suspension of THAAD became permanent,

60.18.text:
it would mark a major breach with
the U.S. on North Korea policy.

65.02.text: The United Arab Emirates is threatening anyone who,

67.86.text:
quote, “shows sympathy or
any form of bias towards Qatar”

71.72.text: with up to 15 years in prison and a $136,000 fine.

78.40.text: along with Saudi Arabia, Egypt and others,

84.48.text:
Scientists have found the oldest known
fossils of Homo sapiens in Morocco.

91.42.text:
pre-dating the earliest evidence of
our species by about 100,000 years.

95.90.text:
The fossils were also found thousands
of miles away from that previous site,

99.90.text:
suggesting early Homo sapiens
were evolving across the continent.

105.68.text:
President Trump nominated
Christopher Wray to head the FBI,

109.12.text: calling him a man of, quote, “impeccable credentials.”

112.20.text:
Wray was the Assistant Attorney General
in charge of the Criminal Division

117.56.text: He’s now a criminal defense lawyer,

119.26.text: and represented New Jersey Governor Chris Christie

124.74.text:
Former FBI Director James Comey’s
prepared testimony

127.88.text:
for the Senate Intelligence Committee
hearing tomorrow

130.40.text:
confirms much of what was leaked
to the press after his firing.

137.78.text: and said he had “nothing to do with Russia,”

140.14.text:
and asked what Comey could do to
“lift the cloud” of the Russia investigation.

144.32.text:
Comey will also testify that Trump asked him
to drop the investigation of Michael Flynn

148.70.text: the day after the National Security Advisor was fired—

151.60.text:
a specific request that could be construed
as obstruction of justice.

155.78.text:
Trump’s lawyer says the President feels
vindicated by Comey’s prepared statement.

176.00.text: an Islamic State video from inside Iran

178.60.text:
showing ISIS fighters on a deadly rampage
inside Tehran’s Parliament building.

193.98.text: the gunmen vow to step up attacks inside Iran

197.34.text:
as they execute 11 people
over the course of a four-hour standoff.

201.80.text:
They had assault rifles,
hand grenades and suicide vests.

207.52.text: At the same time, 15 miles away,

209.58.text:
there was gunfire at the mausoleum
of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini,

219.94.text: There has never been an ISIS attack in Iran,

222.24.text: let alone one as brazen as this.

226.42.text:
It was thought the highly-regulated
security environment there

229.62.text: simply didn’t afford space for the group to operate.

233.58.text:
But the Shia-ruled superpower
is a major target for ISIS—

237.14.text:
Iran has given material support to groups
fighting ISIS in both Syria and Iraq.

242.32.text: It’s even sent troops of its own to join those fights.

249.82.text: — ISIS has tried to attack Iran before.

252.54.text: Some previous plots have been foiled—

256.84.text:
— And this video from back in March
showed ISIS fighters speaking in Farsi

260.82.text:
to urge Iranian Sunni ethnic
communities to take up arms.

264.60.text:
We asked an Iran expert about the
terror group’s influence inside Iran:

268.46.text: — Iran is not the organic breeding ground for ISIS.

272.26.text:
But ISIS does have opportunities to exploit
grievances among a grieved Sunni population,

279.88.text: and it does have a community of Sunnis.

283.10.text: And, in that Sunni community that is marginalized,

287.56.text: there has been some support for ISIS.

291.38.text: — The timing of it, what do you make of that?

294.12.text:
— Well, I think a lot of people are
definitely questioning the timing,

297.74.text:
particularly it coming on the back of
President Trump’s recent trip to the Gulf,

303.16.text:
and the Arab unity against Iran as part of
the new counter-terrorism narrative.

311.91.text:
and the Iranians are spinning the story that,
actually, it’s Saudi that’s behind this.

320.34.text: ISIS warned of more to come inside Iran,

322.90.text:
but this attack in itself could
raise tensions to new levels

325.90.text: in a region that’s already on-edge.

345.50.text:
the nation’s top four intelligence leaders testified
in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee,

350.90.text: and none would say whether the President

352.50.text:
asked them to shut down the FBI’s investigation
of ex-National Security Advisor Michael Flynn.

358.94.text: — I have never been directed to do anything

361.14.text:
I believe to be illegal, immoral,
unethical or inappropriate.

365.70.text: — But the hearing was just the undercard:

368.84.text: fired FBI Director James Comey will have his turn.

372.72.text:
The investigation has become a full-time
obsession for much of the country.

376.82.text:
But, for the White House,
it’s anything but entertaining.

380.26.text: According to a new report in the Washington Post,

383.20.text:
staffers have been instructed to retain
their documents and communications records

386.96.text:
in case they get drawn into
the investigation themselves.

390.46.text:
And many are beginning to look for help from
an old and established Washington industry.

398.76.text: — If you’re in Stan Brand’s office,

404.42.text: I’m not a rabbi or a priest.

410.54.text:
— It’s been a long time since Washington was
fixated on a huge, neverending White House scandal.

415.82.text:
The last two occupants saw
nothing like the Bill Clinton years—

419.04.text: when scandal was everywhere, all the time.

422.56.text: What can the insiders at the Clinton White House

425.48.text:
teach us about what’s going on inside
the Trump White House?

433.12.text:
this is George Stephanopoulos,
White House Communications Director.

437.00.text:
He was first subpoenaed in 1994
during the Whitewater investigation,

443.02.text:
— Stephanopoulos recalls this time
in his 1999 book, “All Too Human,”

446.38.text:
which I have here in the original
14-cassette audio version.

451.90.text: a giant of the audiobook world,

453.70.text: and the story of Stephanopoulos’s first subpoena

455.90.text: comes on tape eight, side two:

490.32.text:
— So what do you tell people
when someone comes in

493.72.text:
and says, “Look, I have a sense I might
need a lawyer?”

496.74.text: — Well, the first thing you do is tell them,

500.54.text: and don’t talk to your colleagues about this.

502.72.text: If you want to talk, talk to me,

505.50.text: and go on with your life.

507.26.text:
Now, within usually the first bit of
time of talking to someone,

511.42.text:
you can assess pretty much whether
you think they have any real exposure.

516.32.text: And if they don’t, you can tell them that.

518.72.text: That, I think, if you don’t do anything stupid,

522.44.text: like throw things away or obstruct justice,

527.10.text: — Jon Lenzner is a former federal prosecutor

529.32.text: who now defends people under federal investigation.

532.46.text: He explained how a White House investigation

537.22.text: — So there may be a lower-level or mid-level staffer

541.92.text:
who works for a senior official
that is under investigation.

546.64.text: Those individuals who work for him

548.82.text: may want to hire their own counsel,

551.22.text:
because they may have been privy
to conversations or meetings

556.54.text: that investigators are going to want to ask them about.

560.10.text:
— Stephanopoulos was never charged
with anything related to Whitewater,

563.00.text: but he was served with at least four subpoenas.

566.04.text: He had to testify before a grand jury a couple of times

571.26.text:
Whitewater began with scrutiny of
a single real estate deal in Arkansas.

575.80.text: But it ballooned into a four-year investigation

578.20.text:
that ended with Bill Clinton impeached
for lying to investigators.

582.56.text: His political career survived, his administration survived.

588.66.text: But his story teaches us this:

591.18.text: when you’re a big deal at the White House,

595.20.text: lawyering up is part of the job.

598.16.text:
But it can be part of the job for people
who are a much smaller deal, too.

603.86.text: And I was working for Leon Panetta,

607.46.text: who was the White House Chief of Staff at the time.

614.66.text:
— Needless to say, Jen Palmieri eventually
found herself having to lawyer up too.

619.30.text: — So I was pretty young, I was pretty freaked out.

621.42.text: And some of my older colleagues there told me,

627.76.text: “We should probably hook you up with a lawyer.”

631.96.text: And then I heard from the FBI.

638.44.text: She had to pay for her own legal fees,

640.08.text: which totaled a few thousand dollars.

643.70.text:
and low-level staffers at the White House
don’t make that much.

649.06.text:
Stan told us Stephanopoulos’s legal bills
totalled between 100 and $150,000…

657.80.text:
Other people who worked for Clinton
had to pay even more.

661.16.text: — The Clintons had to go to fundraisers

662.93.text: to fundraise for their staff to pay for legal fees.

666.98.text: — She too was never charged with anything.

669.16.text: Her political career didn’t suffer either:

671.62.text:
she went on to run communications
in the Obama White House

676.50.text: But the Clinton White House operated like this—

682.74.text:
— It would be reported in the press
that someone talked to Bill Clinton,

685.84.text: and that person would get subpoenaed the next day.

689.06.text: So people stopped wanting to talk to the President,

692.22.text: because he was a subpoena magnet.

695.32.text:
— The Trump presidency is entering a phase
where everyone needs a lawyer,

699.04.text: and investigators are scouring everything that happens.

705.70.text: — You were so under siege and under threat,

712.88.text: and the President often lashes out on his own,

716.72.text:
and telling his version of events
even when it gets him in trouble.

720.58.text: Stan says every politico under this threat

726.08.text: But he says it’s not a good idea:

728.04.text: — The best advice is not to talk to the press about this,

734.04.text:
is antithetical to their vision of why
they’re in the government.

739.88.text: — They want to clear their name.

741.52.text: — They want to clear their name.

744.12.text: And what I say to those people is,

746.94.text:
that is something you should tell
to your rabbi or your priest,

750.22.text:
but it’s not going to help you
to tell that to the New York Times.

753.06.text: — How often you will take that advice from you?

756.56.text: And most who don’t, live to rue the day.

774.06.text:
— Tomorrow, Britons will vote in
their next Prime Minister.

778.92.text:
Conservative Theresa May is expected
to hang on as leader of the U.K.

783.12.text: But even after almost 20 years in frontline politics,

789.16.text: And what does she really want to do with her mandate?

791.62.text:
Aditya Chakrabortty examines
the pedigree of the woman

794.54.text: likely to be crowned Queen of Brexit Britain.

799.36.text:
— Here’s what Theresa May
would like you to know about her:

802.32.text: She’s the daughter of a vicar;

807.44.text: she’s, the subtext runs, just like you—

812.80.text: not like David Cameron and his posh chums.

815.80.text:
Except the woman who would
rule Britain is not ordinary at all.

819.46.text: Here she is trying to speak human:

821.22.text:
— We’ll ensure that Britain has
a strong and stable leadership…

830.36.text: — Here she is trying to act human:

832.00.text: — What’s the naughtiest thing you ever did?

836.46.text:
me and my friend sort-of used to
run through the fields of wheat…

839.42.text: the farmers weren’t too pleased about that.

842.00.text:
— And here she is with her husband,
dishing out marriage advice:

845.28.text: — I get to decide when I take the bins out,

848.00.text: not if I take the bins out.

851.72.text: — There’s boy jobs and girl jobs, you see.

857.60.text:
how you sit on a studio sofa is as important
as where you stand on cyber security—

864.58.text:
In a business that demands a
photogenic family, she’s childless—

868.28.text: as Conservative rivals are not above pointing out.

871.10.text: As a public figure, she’s introverted.

874.32.text: Her number two at the Home Office

875.80.text: recalls May throwing a Christmas office lunch…

879.96.text: — I thought I would liven the place up,

884.92.text: which of course they weren't really used to,

887.30.text: and they were kind of laughing rather absurdly.

892.12.text: well, that was an interesting experience,

894.86.text:
and God bless her, at least she’s
giving us a free Christmas lunch.

897.44.text: And then, three or four days later,

898.96.text: each of the ministers got a bill for £58.74.

902.48.text:
— Yet May has spent nearly
20 years at the top of politics and,

905.48.text:
when Cameron stepped down after
losing last summer’s Brexit referendum,

911.28.text:
— I’m delighted to have won so much
support from my colleagues.

915.82.text: — A win tomorrow will hand May her own mandate,

919.00.text: at just the point Brexit Britain rewrites the rules

921.56.text: on everything from GM crops to foreign policy.

926.02.text: May has offered a kind of faith-based leadership,

928.42.text: telling voters she’ll be a great leader—

930.52.text: without detailing the policies she plans to lead on.

935.76.text: she’s ducked out of the TV debates.

938.00.text: — Prime Minister, if you’re so strong,

939.94.text: and Jeremy Corbyn is so weak, as you said,

942.40.text:
why have you sent Amber Rudd to take on
his arguments at the debate tonight?

952.06.text:
She basically has to get to polling day
without making a mistake.

955.70.text:
So I think she's kind-of kept in defense
rather than going out on attack.

962.50.text: — We do know she’s no ideologue,

964.36.text:
but it’s what causes she adopts
and how that’s so striking.

967.86.text: As modern Britain’s longest-serving Home Secretary,

970.66.text: her key policy was a hand-me-down:

972.68.text: a pledge to slash immigration numbers.

977.62.text: but the right-wing press demanded it,

981.14.text: sending these vans into inner-city areas.

985.38.text:
The same goes for the issue
that will define her premiership:

988.86.text: Before the vote, May fought for Britain to stay in Europe.

992.18.text:
Ever since, she’s been more hardline
than many Brexiteers.

997.88.text: and we’re going to make a success of it.

1002.30.text: — Cheered on by the same Eurosceptic press.

1005.02.text: Stack it all up and May is a populist—

1007.74.text: just one who doesn’t like people.

1009.80.text: Amid political flux and economic slump,

1012.46.text:
she’s trying to stave off a
structural crisis of Conservatism.

1016.16.text: She doesn’t bring in new ideas,

1019.88.text: — If you believe you’re a citizen of the world,

1023.70.text:
— Now where have you heard
that kind of rhetoric before?

1027.10.text:
This project of populism from above
is being driven these two:

1030.94.text: Special Advisors Fiona Hill and Nick Timothy.

1033.98.text:
Americans may be used to such
powerful unelected officials.

1037.42.text: In Britain, they’re an unwelcome novelty.

1039.90.text: She was clearly competent and intelligent,

1042.72.text:
but she relied to a disproportionate and
strange degree on her two special advisors,

1048.74.text: even when their judgment was clearly wrong.

1051.48.text:
She would want to go along with
what they were suggesting,

1054.02.text: although her judgement, in my view,

1058.66.text:
especially as all the government’s
Brexit decisions are going through Timothy.

1066.28.text: equals a recipe for disaster in the Brexit-wrangling.

1070.92.text: She does things on the merit.

1072.76.text: And that's why people, the conventional politicians,

1078.10.text:
— So how’s that going to play out when she's
dealing with conventional politicians of Europe?

1082.34.text: — The deal has got to be good for Britain.

1084.92.text: She will walk away from the table if necessary.

1088.40.text: — If May’s looked so tortured in this campaign,

1090.66.text: she reflects the contortions of the Conservatism—

1093.38.text:
the oldest party in the world is only
just catching up with the new populism.

1097.34.text:
The political arm of business
is pushing through a policy—

1102.62.text:
What do you get when you reconcile
these irreconcilables?

1106.68.text: The answer appears to be Theresa May…

1117.86.text:
advertisements have followed you around
the internet based on what you type.

1123.94.text: is offering the next wave of ad-tracking:

1129.46.text:
that can target ads to you
based on the pictures you post.

1133.10.text:
— Let’s say you take a selfie and you’re
wearing a certain brand of sneakers.

1138.24.text: The neural network is able to detect that in real time,

1142.18.text:
and then follow you into whichever
mobile app or mobile website you open next.

1146.54.text:
So let’s say you close Instagram and
you open the Huffington Post app—

1151.10.text: there, you might get an ad created from Under Armor.

1156.04.text:
— The technology works by breaking
an image down into sections for analysis,

1159.74.text:
and comparing them with information
it’s been previously fed

1162.69.text: about what a can of Coke or a pizza looks like.

1165.98.text:
Cluep has already done work for
Coca-Cola, McDonald’s and Wal-Mart,

1169.80.text: and photo tracking seems primed to grow:

1172.52.text:
Cluep estimates that we share
nearly half a billion images

1175.32.text: to Twitter, Facebook and Instagram every day.

1178.68.text: — In the same way that inputs from a keyboard

1181.00.text:
became the starting point for most marketers
to target people on desktop computers,

1185.54.text: we believe that the inputs from a camera screen

1188.12.text: is the starting point for targeting on smartphones.

1190.86.text: — Advertisers are increasingly desperate for ways

1192.76.text: to get the attention of a saturated audience.

1195.56.text:
Cluep says, after running
500 campaigns for 200 brands,

1199.14.text: that it gets more people clicking on ads than the other,

1201.64.text: more conventional means of targeting you.

1203.98.text:
So it’s likely that lots of other companies
will start to track your photographs too,

1208.64.text: and the arms race for your attention will continue.

1214.00.text: So soon, there’ll be nowhere that brands can’t find you.

1234.70.text: — Have you ever heard the Windsor Hum?

1237.92.text: and I've heard a lot of people who have heard it, so...

1246.54.text: but it could be your mind playing tricks on you.

1249.72.text: — In Windsor, Ontario, across the river from Detroit,

1252.82.text: hundreds of residents complain of a low rumbling.

1255.54.text:
It’s one that keeps them up at night
and rattles their windows—

1258.76.text: and it’s been loud enough to crack eggs.

1261.30.text:
But no one knows for sure
where the sound comes from.

1264.76.text: — This is the west recorder, because that's west.

1267.62.text: Back there in the corner, you can’t even see it,

1272.20.text: And then way over here is the north recorder.

1274.56.text:
And they get synced and pulled off
and put back out every 24 to 48 hours.

1279.80.text:
— There are 1,500 members in
the Windsor Hum Facebook group,

1282.90.text:
who have dedicated themselves to
tracking down the origins of the hum.

1289.20.text: He lives in a town called Olde Sandwich,

1291.60.text: and it’s apparently where the hum is loudest.

1294.04.text:
— So you guys have collected a terabyte
of audio recordings on this thing.

1298.66.text: — Actually, no. I've got about eight terabytes.

1301.58.text: Okay, I wanna hear what this thing sounds like.

1305.12.text: — Understand this vibrates on the floor and everything,

1307.60.text: so you're not really getting it clear.

1309.84.text: But it'll give you an idea.

1324.68.text: — Provost is pretty sure that the hum is America’s fault.

1327.88.text:
More specifically, he thinks that
it’s coming from Zug Island,

1334.66.text:
The island, located in the Detroit River
nearly five miles from Detroit,

1340.56.text:
and the company won’t say
what specifically goes on there.

1343.76.text:
It’s closely guarded by private guards
and Homeland Security officials,

1348.06.text: but we tried to get as close as we could.

1350.24.text: — You can’t go as the crow flies.

1352.06.text:
Unless we had a helicopter,
which we don’t have today.

1355.46.text:
— Kevin Bacchus is a charter fishing
captain who works in Detroit.

1359.38.text: — I don't really know much about what's down there.

1362.12.text: People say stay away from there, but I don't know why.

1365.62.text: So all this black shit, that's Zug Island?

1371.36.text: — I don't even know about none of this shit, brother.

1375.44.text: — But you can hear it, you can hear this horrible noise.

1379.06.text:
“This is a restricted area defined
by Homeland Security regulations.”

1383.20.text:
Yeah, I mean, it's kind of similar to
what we were hearing across the river.

1387.28.text: — There's definitely some depth to what I hear.

1394.01.text: they may not be able to hear this machine.

1395.97.text: They might only be able to hear that low rumble.

1399.18.text: That's just what I'm guessing from what I'm hearing.

1401.82.text: But what the heck do I know?

1402.94.text: I'm a fishing charter captain, for Christ's sake.

1407.42.text:
— In a 2014, the Canadian government
commissioned a report about the hum,

1410.88.text:
which we obtained through
the Freedom of Information Act.

1413.62.text: Researchers set up microphones around Windsor.

1416.22.text: But, due to some cross-border politics,

1418.56.text: they weren’t allowed to investigate on Zug Island itself.

1422.50.text:
The report concludes that the sound
is most likely coming from Zug Island,

1426.32.text: but that they can't be sure.

1429.26.text:
And no one’s positive why only the
Canadian side of the river can hear it.

1434.64.text: — As far as I'm concerned, it's the Detroit Hum.

1436.92.text: It's not the Windsor Hum, because we don't emit it.

1440.58.text: There's nothing much we can do on the Canadian side,

1442.06.text: we have nothing between Canada and the United States

1444.40.text: that actually deals with noise and vibration.

1446.40.text: You can call it what you want,

1447.34.text:
but, at the end of the day, it’s not
good for international relations.

1451.48.text: — It’s that frequency that is driving us crazy.

1455.62.text: All’s we have to do is have somebody come up and say,

1459.54.text:
“we’re working on muffling it,
and we don’t think we can fix it…”

1471.00.text:
— That's VICE News Tonight
for Wednesday, June 7th.
